docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory commission that will study the future of Medicare kicked off a year of work today with members declaring a desire for bipartisan agreement but skirmishing over President Clinton's proposal to open the program to millions of people 55 to 64 years old. One member, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, former chief economic adviser to Mr. Clinton, cited new data from the Congressional Budget Office to show that his proposal would not increase the Federal deficit or harm the Medicare trust fund.

headline.main: Study Panel On Medicare Begins Work, In Conflict

docs.abstract: Federal advisory commission on future of Medicare, 17-member panel that includes 10 members of Congress, begins work; members cite desire for bipartisan accord but skirmish over Pres Clinton's bid to open program to people 55 to 64 years old; panel member Laura D'Andrea Tyson cites new Congressional Budget Office data to show proposal would not increase Federal deficit or harm Medicare trust fund (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael H. had not had a shave or haircut in months when he was found one recent morning sleeping on the floor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in suburban Lancaster, next to empty cans of tuna and soup from the church pantry. There was little to suggest that he had once been a prosperous college graduate with a wife and two children -- until he developed schizophrenia, lost his job and, without insurance, could no longer afford the drugs needed to control his mental illness.

headline.main: ASYLUMS BEHIND BARS: A special report.; Prisons Replace Hospitals for the Nation's Mentally Ill

docs.abstract: Fox Butterfield, in special report Asylums Behind Bars, says Los Angeles County Jail, by default, is nation's largest mental institution; it holds 1,500 to 1,700 inmates who are severely mentally ill, most of them detained on minor charges; situation in jail, criticized as unconstitutional by Justice Dept, is most visible evidence that jails and prisons have become nation's new mental hospitals; almost 200,000 people are behind bars on any day; more than 1 in 10 of total are known to suffer from schizophrenia, manic depression or major depression; rate is four times that in general population; there is evidence, particularly with juveniles, that numbers in jail are growing; what experts call criminalization of mentally ill has grown as issue as nation's inmate population has exploded and as corrections officials and families of emotionally disturbed have become alarmed by problems posed by having mentally ill behind bars; photos (M)

headline.main: Adding Cumin to the Curry: A Matter of Life and Death

docs.abstract: Cornell University researchers report that people who live in hot climates may like hot foods because spice plants contain powerful antibiotic chemicals capable of killing or suppressing bacteria and fungi that commonly contaminate and spoil foods and can poison those who eat them; spices that are prominent in traditional dishes from tropical and subtropical regions are used with much lighter hand, if at all, in countries and regions where climate is colder; chart compares use of various hot foods and spices in India and Norway (L)
